holidays.name: International Ugly Christmas Sweater Day
holidays.description: A festive day encouraging people to don their most hideous, tacky, and over-the-top Christmas sweaters. It's all about embracing the goofy holiday spirit with knitwear that’s loud and proudly embarrassing.
holidays.origin: Started in the early 2010s as a fun excuse to wear the sweaters that people usually hide in the back of their closets until next year.
holidays.funFact: The tradition has inspired ugly sweater parties and even national contests for the most extravagantly ugly Christmas sweater!

holidays.name: Festivus
holidays.description: A parody holiday made famous by the TV show Seinfeld, featuring the Airing of Grievances and Feats of Strength instead of traditional holiday cheer.
holidays.origin: Created by writer Dan O'Keefe and popularized by Seinfeld in the 1990s as a humorous alternative to commercial holiday madness.
holidays.funFact: Festivus is celebrated with a bare aluminum pole instead of a Christmas tree – because it’s 'very shiny and very strong.'

holidays.name: National Hard Candy Day
holidays.description: A sweet day to celebrate all those colorful, hard candies that have been a holiday candy staple for decades.
holidays.origin: An unofficial food holiday with unclear origins but cherished by candy lovers worldwide.
holidays.funFact: Peppermint hard candies and candy canes often see a big spike in sales this time of year, making hard candy a holiday superstar.

holidays.name: Look for an Evergreen Day
holidays.description: Encourages people to appreciate the evergreen trees around them, symbolizing resilience and everlasting life during winter months.
holidays.origin: An obscure observance aimed at boosting appreciation for winter greenery and nature's persistence.
holidays.funFact: Evergreens like pines and firs not only stay green all winter but also have been used for centuries in holiday decorations to symbolize eternal life.
